newsitem.title: USA: Chase, Citicorp earnings rose in quarter.
newsitem.headline: Chase, Citicorp earnings rose in quarter.

text.p: Chase Manhattan Corp. and Citicorp, the nation's two largest banks, on Tuesday reported earnings gains for the second quarter despite some weakness in credit card and consumer banking operations.

Mellon Bank Corp., based in Pittsburgh, also said its earnings rose, up 6 percent. But Banc One Corp. of Ohio, the nation's eighth-largest bank, and No. 9 Wells Fargo & Co. of California both said earnings fell, hurt by one-time costs related to acquisitions.
The results met or slightly exceeded expectations on Wall Street, as did earnings reported by Nationsbank, First Chicago NBD Corp. and other big banks on Monday.

Chase, which took over the No. 1 spot from Citicorp when it acquired Chemical Bank last year, said net income rose to $925 million, or $2 a share, in the quarter ended on June 30, compared with $856 million, or $1.83 a share, a year earlier.

Chase, based in New York, cited strength in its corporate business worldwide and a rise in revenue from trading for its own account, partly offset by weakness in credit cards and other consumer banking businesses, where earnings declined.

Excluding restructuring costs from the Chemical merger, Chase earnings were $969 million, or $2.11 a share, which was above the $2.07 a share forecast by analysts, according to First Call, which tracks Wall Street estimates.
Chase delivered a "positive surprise," said analyst Robert Albertson at Goldman, Sachs & Co. Chase stock rose $1 to $103 in late trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Citicorp, also based in New York, said earnings rose to $1.02 billion in the quarter from $952 million a year earlier, while earnings per share increased to $2.10 from $1.86.

The results were a penny above analysts' forecast of $2.09 a share, according to First Call, but Citicorp stock fell $2.125 to $126.375 on the NYSE as investors wondered whether the bank's days of rapid growth were over.
Several analysts said Citicorp's domestic credit card business did poorly in the quarter, but George Salem at Gerard Klauer Mattison said the company's problems appeared more widespread.
"Citicorp is not doing well, period," he said. "Where's the growth? I think this is a turning point for Citicorp. They have a real challenge ahead of them."

Earnings in Citicorp's consumer businesses, which include its retail branches, credit cards and its private bank, fell 3 percent for the second consecutive quarter. Earnings in its other main business, corporate banking, rose 5 percent.

Chairman John Reed cited "challenges" in the credit card business and said "the highly competitive marketplace is a permanent reality," adding that Citicorp would focus on service and cutting costs to bolster results in the card and retail businesses.
Wells Fargo, based in San Francisco, said net income fell to $228 million, or $2.49 a share, in the quarter, from $363 million, or $3.61 a share, a year earlier.

The results were close to forecasts of $2.52 a share after the bank said last week that earnings would suffer because of troubles integrating First Interstate, which it acquired last year for about $11 billion in stock.
"The results were not much worse than they warned. They were basically in the range," Stephen Biggar at S&P Equity Group said.
Wells stock rose $1.50 to $267 on the NYSE, recovering some of its 6.6 percent drop after its earnings warning last Wednesday.

One analyst said the troubles were because it was not a friendly merger. "I have a feeling it has a lot to with the the fact it was a hostile merger. A lot of top managers left Interstate when the deal closed. At this stage, you have to wonder if it would have gone a lot more smoothly had they stuck around," the analyst said.

Banc One said net income fell to $16 million, or 2 cents a share, from $395 million, or 66 cents a share, a year earlier. The latest quarter included a $467 million pretax charge related to its acquisitions of Liberty Bancorp Inc. in Oklahoma and First USA Inc. completed during the quarter.

Excluding the charge and previously announced accounting adjustments, Banc One said earnings fell to $391.6 million in the quarter from $395.2 million. Banc One stock fell 25 cents to $48.69 on the NYSE.

Mellon Bank, the No. 23 bank, said net income rose to $190 million, or 72 cents a share, in the quarter, from $179 million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier. The results came in a penny above forecasts.
Mellon also said it would buy back up to 6 million more shares, or 2.4 percent of its stock, and the shares added $1.125 to $48.31 on the NYSE.
